Award.AwardTitle: CELEST: A Center of Excellence for Learning in Education, Science, and Technology

Directorate.LongName: Direct For Social, Behav & Economic Scie

Award.AbstractNarration:
CELEST seeks to understand the fundamental processes that underlie human learning by studying dynamic interactions within and among brain regions. Interdisciplinary research teams study how the brain learns to (1) plan: to make decisions for appropriate actions based on assessment of risks and potential rewards in a given situation, (2) explore: to perform planned actions to move about familiar and unfamiliar environments, (3) communicate: to use noisy and incomplete sensory information to interact effectively with other agents and objects in the world, and (4) remember: to encode and guide retrieval of information to achieve goals. CELEST is a multi-faceted collaboration that focuses the efforts of scientific and educational teams led by 15 senior scientists at four Boston-area universities. CELEST combines undergraduate and graduate training in interdisciplinary research that combines experimental cognitive neuroscience with quantitative behavioral and brain modeling of normal and abnormal learning during perception, cognition, emotion, and action.

Broader impacts: CELEST transfers the results of basic research on learning to undergraduate and graduate courses. This is achieved through its ongoing development of course materials for the new undergraduate neuroscience major at Boston University, and through electronic dissemination on the CELEST web site. Outreach to the undergraduate neuroscience community also occurs by means of a one-day CELEST workshop and related workbook about the cognitive basis of successful learning strategies. A number of CELEST programs are targeted at increasing opportunities for groups underrepresented in science to participate in its innovative curriculum and research initiatives. These include graduate fellowships, summer internships for faculty from minority-serving institutions, a ten-week summer program for undergraduates from underrepresented groups to work in CELEST faculty labs, and a week-long summer workshop to introduce undergraduates to the interplay of modeling and experimental techniques in cognitive neuroscience. Center added value: By bringing together distinct scientific communities that traditionally employ different practices and techniques, CELEST interdisciplinary science is changing the way we understand how the brain learns, and how different parts of the brain interact with each other during learning. Through collaboration with industrial partners, including the development and transfer of large-scale neuromorphic engineering and technological algorithms to industry and government laboratories, CELEST facilitates research for practical applications that cannot be supported by conventional single-investigator grants. CELEST faculty, postdocs, and students are playing increasingly important roles in communicating with non-specialists through many activities including blogs, workshops, and presentations to secondary school audiences. The integration of CELEST research and education is accomplished through the development of innovative curriculum materials based upon mathematical and computational models of mind and brain. through electronic and personal presentations to a variety of audiences, and through sponsorship of scientific conferences and workshops.

POR.DRECONTENT:
By understanding the principles of how the brain learns as a whole system, CELEST enabled the design of intelligent technologies that adapt to meet human needs. Towards this goal, CELEST promoted an innovative integration of experimental (bench), theoretical (models), and technical (applications) approaches to scientific research and graduate education. The projects within CELEST integrated a least two of three approaches: experiments, modeling, and technology development. Basic scientific work in CELEST differed from most research on the neuroscience of learning in its emphasis on whole-brain interactions, rather than focusing on learning in specific neural regions. CELEST’s technology development is informed by a deep understanding of how living organisms learn, incorporating actual neural mechanisms into algorithms and systems. This "neuromorphic approach" (developing technology bby building on the processing architecture of the human brain) differentiated CELEST from most other research focused on building adaptive agents and systems.

CELEST projects were chosen because they represented areas of opportunity for increasing the impact of our research by more tightly coordinating work across individual research projects, something that is impossible with smaller research grants. The approximately 80 projects funded in Year 6-10 have produced approximately 160 peer-reviewed journal publications, an average of 2 publications per funded project-year. Many of these publications and presentations can be unambiguously and directly attributed to the center mode of funding.

CELEST also had a major impact in the area of education. The foundation of CELEST was based at Boston University. Over the decade of CELEST funding, BU administration complementrf this successful research program with two new academic programs: the Undergraduate Program in Neuroscience and the Graduate Program in Neuroscience. These programs are very successful in both recruitment of students and outstanding faculty.

One of CELEST’s largest accomplishments was in training postdocs, graduate, and undergraduate in projects combining computational, experimental, and technological aspects of the neuroscience of learning. CELEST graduate students were encouraged to choose courses that span experimental, modeling, and technological aspects of neuroscience. CELEST’s main strategy was to ensure comprehensive training at the PhD level to require that all supported projects have at least two faculty mentors for every graduate student or postdoctoral associate. Each funded project spanned at least two of the three areas of experimentation, modeling, and technological application. As a result, each graduate student or postdoctoral associate was assured of gaining direct experience in at least two of the three modalities on every project.

Trainees supported by CELEST now are using their computational and technical training in both academia and high tech industry, in roughly equal proportion. Of the 56 postdocs trained through CELEST, 18 (32%) are now professors, 18 (32%) work in the high tech industry, 10 (18%) are in non-professorial permanent positions in academia, 6 (11%) are postdocs, 1 (2%) is a practicing physician, and we have no information about 3 (5%). Of our former postdocs who are professors, six already have tenure.  Of the 161 graduate students trained by CELEST, 65 (40%) remain in academia, 61 (38%) went into high tech industry, 5 (3.1%) went into the financial industry, 4 (2.5%) went into K12 education, 2 (1.2%) are in medicine, and we have no information about 24 (14.9%). Of the former graduate students who remain in academia, 18 (11%) are professors and 18 (11%) have other permanent positions. These percentages attest to the strength of the technical training afforded by our research center, and the long-term impact this training will have on STEM in the United States.

Our summer undergraduate training program, held each summer for the final half of CELEST, provided significant outreach. We successfully reached a good percentage of trainees from under-represented groups (including under-represented minorities, women, and first-generation college attendees). These efforts addressed "pipeline" issues in striving for diversity in STEM. The program included professional development seminars covering various issues, including on how graduate training is funded, what a successful graduate application looks like, how implicit bias can influence careers, how to organize scientific presentations, how to write effective papers, and other topics.

Finally, CELEST has had a significant impact in transitioning the technologies  into the private sector. Many CELEST graduate students have participated in internships at companies including Hewlett-Packard. Several patents were filed by CELEST researchers. CELEST board members Frank Guenther, Barbara Shinn-Cunningham, Tim Gardner, and Heather Ames have been actively participating in technology transfer activities such as patent filings, engaging in sponsored research activities, and founded companies.

One of the biggest such successes was the founding of Neurala Inc. by CELEST faculty members, Heather Ames, Max Versace, and Anatoli Gorshechnikov. Neurala has raised tens of millions of dollars in venture funding to productize machine learning concepts inspired by CELEST research. Two other companies were founded by CELEST-trained personnel: Kernel Insights (founded by former postoc Chaitanya Sai Gaddam) and Senter LLC (founded by former PhD student Sean Lorenz).
